questions.text: When the fetal head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor, which of the following is true?

options.label: D
options.text: May lead to deep transverse arrest

questions.correct_answer: A. Outlet Forceps can be applied
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Outlet Forceps can be applied

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When the fetal head is at the perineum and the skull has reached the pelvic floor, it is an appropriate time to consider the application of outlet forceps to assist in the delivery of the baby's head.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 23y primigravida is undergoing an elective LSCS for breech presentation. What is the ideal timing of cesarean section?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 39 Weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ideal timing for elective cesarean sections should consider the balance between fetal maturity and the avoidance of complications associated with preterm or post-term birth. In the case of a primigravida with a breech presentation, scheduling the cesarean section around 39 weeks of gestation is often recommended to optimize the baby's readiness for birth while minimizing the risk of neonatal complications.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Prerequisite for outlet forceps application are all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Station 0 or +1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's important to assess the engagement of the fetal head, cervical dilation, the presence of uterine contractions, and the station of the baby's head to determine the appropriate timing for forceps application during childbirth. The outlet forceps are applied when station of fetal head is ≥ +3 station and not at 0 or +1.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 39 y primigravida female presents in labor with breech presentation at 38 weeks. She has conceived via IVF. She has multiple large fibroids in the anterior lower uterine segment. The most appropriate management is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Classical cesarean

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A cesarean section is often recommended for breech presentations, especially in primigravida women, as it reduces the risks associated with delivering a baby in a breech position. When the lower uterine segment is not approachable due to multiple large fibroids in the lower segment, classical cesarean section (upper segment cesarean) may be done. Indications for a classical cesarean section include: Large fibroid in the lower segment Dense adhesions in the lower segmenr Placenta accreta syndrome Carcinoma cervix Perimortem cesarean section
  • ➤ A cesarean section is often recommended for breech presentations, especially in primigravida women, as it reduces the risks associated with delivering a baby in a breech position.
  • ➤ When the lower uterine segment is not approachable due to multiple large fibroids in the lower segment, classical cesarean section (upper segment cesarean) may be done.
  • ➤ Indications for a classical cesarean section include: Large fibroid in the lower segment Dense adhesions in the lower segmenr Placenta accreta syndrome Carcinoma cervix Perimortem cesarean section
  • ➤ Large fibroid in the lower segment Dense adhesions in the lower segmenr Placenta accreta syndrome Carcinoma cervix Perimortem cesarean section
  • ➤ Large fibroid in the lower segment
  • ➤ Dense adhesions in the lower segmenr
  • ➤ Placenta accreta syndrome
  • ➤ Carcinoma cervix
  • ➤ Perimortem cesarean section
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1442, Willaims Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1442, Willaims Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: All are the contraindications for vaginal birth after previous cesarean except?

options.label: D
options.text: Where facilities for emergency cesareans are not available

questions.correct_answer: B. Previous lower segment transverse cesarean
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Previous lower segment transverse cesarean

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ While VBAC can be a safe option for some women with a previous cesarean section, certain factors, such as the type of previous uterine incision and the availability of emergency resources, need to be considered to make informed decisions about the mode of delivery.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1492, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1492, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Indications for cesarean hysterectomy are all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Couvelaire uterus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A Caesarean hysterectomy is a life-saving measure in cases of severe obstetric emergencies such as placenta accreta, atonic uterus with uncontrolled PPH, or ruptured uterus.
  • ➤ Page 1910 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Page 1910 Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A second Para who has had an uncomplicated lower segment cesarean section in her first pregnancy is in labor. She is allowed a trial of vaginal delivery. What is the earliest warning sign of scar rupture?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Fetal distress

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Fetal distress, as manifested by changes in the fetal heart rate pattern, is often one of the earliest and most significant warning signs
  • ➤ Ref: Page 149, 6Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 149, 6Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Contraindication of vacuum extraction are all except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Internal rotation incomplete

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vacuum can be applied even when internal rotation is incomplete.
  • ➤ Vacuum can be applied even when internal rotation is incomplete.
  • ➤ ReF: Page 1392, Wiliams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ ReF: Page 1392, Wiliams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which statement is true regarding Ventouse (vacuum extractor)?

options.label: A
options.text: Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps

options.label: B
options.text: Can be applied when fetal head is above the level of ischial spine

options.label: C
options.text: Maternal trauma is more frequent than forceps

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be used when fetal head is not fully rotated

questions.correct_answer: A. Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Minor scalp abrasions and subgaleal hematomas in newborn are more frequent than forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ It is important to weigh the benefits and risks of using vacuum extraction in each case, considering factors such as fetal position, maternal condition, and the potential for minor newborn injuries. Vacuum has a feature of autorotation; so even if internal rotation is not complete – traction on the vacuum will cause rotation
  • ➤ It is important to weigh the benefits and risks of using vacuum extraction in each case, considering factors such as fetal position, maternal condition, and the potential for minor newborn injuries. Vacuum has a feature of autorotation; so even if internal rotation is not complete – traction on the vacuum will cause rotation
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1395, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1395, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: The following is always an indication of cesarean section except?

options.label: B
options.text: Untreated stage of I B Ca cervix

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Abruptio placentae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ It's important to recognize that while some conditions (like major placenta previa and active genital herpes) commonly necessitate a C-section, others (like placental abruption) require a more nuanced approach based on individual circumstances.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1412, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A forceps rotation of 30° from left occiput anterior (OA) to OA with extraction of the fetus from +2 station would be described as which type of delivery?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Low forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Outlet forceps delivery is indicated when the fetal head is at or on the perineum. Low forceps delivery is indicated when the leading point of the skull is at station +2 or more but not on the pelvic floor.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1367, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: An episiotomy is to be performed in a primigravida in labor. Which of these is an advantage of mediolateral episiotomy over midline episiotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Less chance of extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ A mediolateral episiotomy is associated with less chances of extension, compared to a midline episiotomy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A. Episiotomy scissor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A pregnant female presents with prolonged labor in emergency. She is taken for a cesarean section. What is the correct position in which the nurse should keep the patient on OT table?

options.label: A
options.text: Supine with wedge under right hip

questions.correct_answer: A. Supine with wedge under right hip
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Supine with wedge under right hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The correct position for a woman undergoing a cesarean section is A, Supine with a Wedge under the Right Hip. This positioning minimizes aortocaval compression, ensuring better blood flow and oxygenation for both the mother and the fetus, and provides the surgeon with appropriate access to perform the cesarean section safely and effectively.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1413, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 1413, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A resident is teaching the intern how to apply a vacuum in the 2 nd stage of labor. After applying the cup at the flexion point, the intern feels around the cup to make sure no maternal tissue is entrapped. Then the vacuum apparatus is turned on to created pressure. What is the pressure created in vacuum?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 0.8 kg/cm2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct pressure used in vacuum-assisted deliveries is 0.8 kg/cm². This level of pressure is considered safe and effective for assisting in the delivery of a baby during the second stage of labor .
  • ➤ Ref : Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th Edition page:563
  • ➤ Ref : Williams Textbook of Obstetrics 25 th Edition page:563

questions.text: Conditions which are contraindicated for vacuum extractions are all; EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Occipito-posterior position

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While face presentation, extreme prematurity, and fetal coagulopathies pose significant risks and are generally contraindications for the use of vacuum extraction, the occipito-posterior position does not inherently preclude the safe use of this method.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1365, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1365, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A baby had this complication following a difficult delivery as described by the mother. What could have caused this complication?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely cause of facial nerve palsy following a difficult delivery is Forceps Delivery. This method can exert significant pressure on the baby's face, leading to nerve injury.
  • ➤ ReF: Page no 1371, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ ReF: Page no 1371, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which structure is NOT cut in a mediolateral episiotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Obturator muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In summary, the structure that is NOT cut in a mediolateral episiotomy is B, the Obturator Muscles. These muscles are located deeper and more laterally in the pelvis and are not involved in the episiotomy incision. The purpose of a mediolateral episiotomy is to enlarge the vaginal opening for childbirth, involving an incision through the perineal skin and potentially affecting the bulbospongiosus and transverse perineal muscles.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A 23y woman is undergoing a cesarean section for obstructed labor. The head is deeply engaged and delivered with difficulty. Following delivery, you notice that the uterine incision has extended and is bleeding profusely having caused avulsion of the uterine arteries. Which instrument will you use to hold the angles of the uterine incision?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Green Armitage Forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Green-Armitage Forceps are specially designed for situations encountered in obstetric surgery, such as holding the angles of a uterine incision during a cesarean section with complications like extended incisions and bleeding. They provide the necessary grip and stability to manage the surgical field effectively and safely.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 696, DC Duttas Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 696, DC Duttas Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: A 1 st year resident is doing a cesareans section for the 1 st time. How will you help her identify the lower uterine segment?

options.label: A
options.text: It appears slightly more pink than the upper segment

options.label: B
options.text: It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum

options.label: C
options.text: It is just below the round ligaments

options.label: D
options.text: It is where the presenting part can be palpated

questions.correct_answer: B. It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. It lies under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The lower uterine segment in a cesarean section is best identified as the area lying under the loose uterovesical fold of peritoneum. This anatomical landmark provides a reliable guide for surgeons to make a safe and effective incision, minimizing the risk of injury to the bladder and ensuring optimal surgical outcomes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1426, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1426, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Identify this instrument shown in the image which is placed vaginally and is used to elevate the fetal head in a difficult cesarean section where the head is deeply engaged:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Fetal pillow

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Fetal Pillow, is an instrument used to elevate the fetal head in a difficult cesarean section where the head is deeply engaged. This tool is part of various methods employed to facilitate the safe and efficient delivery of the baby, especially in challenging situations where there is a risk of extension of incisions and bleeding
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1430, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1430, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: What is the first structure to be sutured following a median episiotomy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Mucosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The correct approach to suturing an episiotomy involves starting with the vaginal mucosa, followed by the muscle layer, and finally the skin. This method ensures effective hemostasis, alignment for optimal healing, and restoration of anatomical and functional integrity of the perineal region. The suture material used is often a rapidly absorbable suture like Vicryl rapid or catgut, which reduces the need for suture removal and provides comfort to the patient
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1306, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
